p:
While these spatial level correlations are striking, it is necessary to characterize the climate drivers of transmission in order to model possible future changes to RSV dynamics. We calculate an empirical transmission rate based on the discrete time version of the susceptible–infected–recovered (TSIR) model using

, assuming we can approximate the first RSV infection as immunizing given that secondary infections are less severe and less infectious

\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\alpha$$\end{document}
α
captures heterogeneities in mixing and the effects of discretization. In order to estimate
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$S$$\end{document}
S
, the number of susceptibles, which is not directly observed within our dataset, we fit the TSIR model to each location and extract the time series of susceptibles from the mean model fit.
